title: Challenger, Schroders take ETF fight to ASX
text:
Mr Jokovic anticipates the launch will force the ASX into more competitive pricing in its bid to secure business from fund managers pursuing listed products.

“The ETF issuers, even the passive ones, let alone the active ones, have [until now] had no avenue to get lower fees,” he said.

“We suspect the ASX will respond as more funds come on to Chi-X with lower listing and trading fees. [The ASX] is a great business because a number of its key revenue streams are monopoly revenue streams – and [ETFs] was one of those.

“We’re slowly bringing competition to additional parts of the exchange market.”

Kapstream managing director Steve Goldman said Challenger chose Chi-X over the ASX for its active ETF products due to more attractive costs and lack of any requirements to make portfolio changes.

Chi-X director of products Shane Miller said the ASX’s comparatively more stringent listing rules require some fund managers to make unpalatable adjustments to underlying assets.

“There is more flexibility in our rules at the moment, but we do expect the ASX to catch up over time,” Mr Miller said.

Active ETFs flip to fixed income

Advertisement

Though the Australian ETF market has grown to a value of more than $50 billion, Mr Jokovic said we are “just seeing the start of that explosion”.

Chi-X expects the number of fund managers seeking to list and trade their products on an exchange to accelerate, particularly those specialised in fixed income and bond strategies.

“We have four to five managers coming to the funds market within months and they are all active fixed income managers,” Mr Jokovic said. “There are others looking to bring the same product to the market.”

Mr Goldman, a former fixed income portfolio manager with Goldman Sachs Asset Management in New York, said trading managed funds on an exchange provides investors with liquidity and spares them the administrative barriers associated with unlisted funds.

“I would view the ETF as a channel that is easier for investors to access,” he said. “You don’t have to fill out the lengthy documentation, it’s primitive and difficult for investors.”

In a low interest rate environment, active fixed income ETFs may emerge as an attractive alternative to term deposits, Mr Goldman suggested.

“We take less than 1 per cent annualised volatility,” he said. “Capital preservation is our No. 1 priority. We are probably the lowest risk product out there in the market.”

Advertisement

Ending monopoly power

Mr Jokovic is frank about Chi-X’s objective to steal market share from the ASX and force Australia’s dominant exchange into further fee compression.

“There seems to be less noise around the ASX than other big monopolies,” he said. “Some people still seem to think it is a mutual that acts in the best interests of the brokers, rather than a corporate acting in the best interests of shareholders.”

He estimated that stockbrokers have saved a total of $250 million in fees since Chi-X entered the market, though conceded he can’t take full credit and that technological disruption and other factors have also placed downward pressure on trading-related fees.

He also conceded some elements of monopoly power are more difficult to erode than others.

Australia’s largest trading platform, CommSec, provides access to the Chi-X exchange, including the funds market from today. But other trading platforms and brokerages are “stragglers'', he admitted.

“One of the challenges with the monopoly power has been that people have developed their systems according to the needs of that provider,” he said. “Everything in Australia has been built to an ASX dynamic. Everything is an extra step today in terms of tech.”

Asked to comment on the launch of the Chi-X funds market and suggestion that it may be forced into more competitive pricing, an ASX spokesperson indicated the dominant exchange is unfazed by the development.

"ASX offers over 200 listed exchange-traded products with a market cap of almost $56 billion," the spokesperson said. "ASX is the home of exchange-traded products in Australia."
description: Kapstream Capital, a member of Challenger’s Fidante stable, will be the first fund manager to participate in Chi-X’s active ETF rival market.
